title: The UMC Utrecht NE group: An introduction
text:
Welcome to the blog of the Utrecht Kidney Research & Epidemiological Analyses Team (U-KREAT) at the UMC Utrecht! Here, we will share interesting publications (both from our own group and from other researchers), give updates on conferences we attended, and share posts aimed at laymen (written in understandable Dutch).
To kick things off, today, we had our first get together at the Café Creatinine. Although our group has existed for a longer time, this was given shape in an informal manner. Today marks the first occurrence of our biweekly recurring meeting. These meetings will serve not only as a short moment to connect with each other, but also to discuss currently ongoing projects, discuss articles, give talks, host external speakers, etc.
…
To finish off, I’ll append an R trick to each post (until I run out of tricks)

This post’s R-trick: multicursor
Did you know you can activate a multicursor in R? This allows you to write the same code on multiple lines simultaneously. Great for if you are writing code in bulk! To activate it, simply hold the Alt/Option key and drag the cursor along the lines that you want the cursor to apply to. On some operating systems, you may need to press the Alt/Option key one more time to activate the cursor. Happy bulk-writing!
An example from Stackoverflow

title: Currently ongoing projects
text: We have a number of overarching research lines, within which we perform most of our research. Besides these research lines, we also collaborate with other researchers on the broader spectrum of cardio-kidney-metabolic epidemiological research and methodological development and innovation.

title: Currently ongoing projects
section: Long-term outcomes after acute kidney injury
text:
Long-term outcomes after acute kidney injury
Acute kidney injury is an impactful disease that may have long-lasting consequences affecting the cardio-kidney axis. However, these long-term outcomes remain difficult to investigate due to individual heterogeneity in individuals with acute kidney injury, difficulty in defining acute kidney injury, and reliance on smaller datasets. In this research line, we aim to overcome these shortcomings to elucidate the long-term outcomes after acute kidney injury, both through a predicitve lens and a relational lens.

People working on this

DeniseRobinRoemer






In this line of research, Denise is in the lead. She has written multiple papers on the topic and more analyses are underway. She is responsible for coming up with new avenues within the project, writing papers and performing analyses.








Robin is the principal investigator in this project. He ensures the project is heading in the best direction it can, seeks funding to continue work, and contributes new research ideas. In this role, he supervises Denise.








Roemer provides assistance from the side line based on his experience in investigating acute kidney injury, helping with programming and offering methdological support where needed.

title: Currently ongoing projects
text:
Cardiovascular risk management in CKD
Individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD) receive a plethora of medications and the majority of treatment regimens can be categorised as polypharmacy. However, for most medications, evidence on effectiveness and safety in the CKD population is limited. Given the altered drug metabolism and shorter life expectancy of these people, it is of paramount importance to reassess safety and effectiveness of medications in them. Witholding or deprescribing ineffective or unsafe treatment can help reduce medication-related disease burden and avoid adverse side effects. As randomised trials are rarely feasible in this population, we approach this using modern epidemiological methods.

People working on this

JuliaEllisRoemerRobin






Julia has performed multiple studies to show the extent of polypharmacy in people with CKD. Using both quantitative and qualitative methods, she was able to gave a broad perspective on the burden of polypharmacy and also showed the lack of evidence underlying most drugs contributing to polypharmacy.








Continuing on the work Julia has done, Ellis is investigating the utilisation of guideline-recommended drugs throughout the hospital. Additionally, she will take the lead on multiple projects investigating the safety and effectiveness of different drugs in individuals with CKD.








Roemer is working together with Ellis to shape the different studies she is performing, additionally strengthening the projects’ methodology and providing quality checks on the way data is used and analysed.








Robin has long been working on this, being the supervisor of both Julia and Ellis. He ensures the project’s long-term sustainability, gives direction where needed, and connects the team members with the right collaborators.

title: Currently ongoing projects
text:
Haemodiafiltration as alternative to haemodialysis
Haemodiafiltration (HDF) is a possible alternative to haemodialysis (HD) that uses both diffusion and convection to improve outcomes of individuals on dialysis. The combination of multiple trials have shown benefits of HDF over HD, but more research is needed. The mechanism by which HDF improves outcomes remains unclear, as does the heterogeneity in treatment effects across many populations. In this project, we apply data from multiple trials, as well as large global databases to further investigate the benefit of HDF over HD.

People working on this

SanneRobinRoemer






Sanne is combing her clinical knowledge with her research skills to investigate HDF. She is performing multiple studies to assess the mechanisms through which HDF possibly has a benefit over HD. Additionally, she is working with national and international collaborators to assess the effectiveness of HDF in diverse and underrepresented populations.








Robin has done multiple projects on HDF and has now connected global collaborators that will work together with Sanne to further this research under his supervision.








Roemer has worked with Robin on HDF and is co-supervising Sanne in her work on HDF, providing methodological guidance and aiding in interpreting the results of the different studies.

title: Currently ongoing projects
section: Kidney Tx through the lens of nephrology, immunology, and virology
text:
Kidney Tx through the lens of nephrology, immunology, and virology
Kidney transplantation is a clinical setting in which many different disciplines are brought together. However, research on kidney transplantation often does not combine all these disciplines. To shed new light on their interplay, we are investigating the long-term post-kidney transplantation phase using multidisciplinary data.

People working on this

RoemerRobin






Roemer is using his previous experience in working on kidney disease to set-up this new research line. Combining advanced statistical methodology and high-quality large datasets, he will provide new insights while actively seeking funding to sustain this project.








Robin is working together with Roemer to get this research line up and running, helping out with funding. As a core member of this project, he also helps steer the project in the most relevant direction.

title: Team members
text:
We are a diverse group of researchers, who all bring our own specialties and skills that complement the team.




Robin W. M. Vernooij
ORCID: 0000-0001-5734-4566
Robin is an assistant professor at the UMC Utrecht, and spearheads this research group. He received his PhD on improving guideline methodology and reporting from the Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona (Spain). Having previously worked at Cochrane and the Dutch Cancer Registry, and currently working as epidemiologist at the Dutch Kidney Registry, Robin’s academic work is strengthened by ample experience in registry research and evidence synthesis.






Roemer J. Janse
ORCID: 0000-0003-0059-872X
Roemer is a clinical epidemiologist, working on the interplay of nephrology, immunology, and virology in kidney transplantation recipients. He completed his BSc in Medicine and afterwards finished his PhD on causal inference and prediction modelling in people with CKD, at the Leiden University Medical Center (The Netherlands) and Karolinska Institutet (Sweden). Besides his clinical projects, he provides epidemiological and programming support.






Cindy P. Porras
ORCID: 0000-0001-7692-9164
Cindy is a medical doctor and clinical epidemiologist, applying her knowledge to the cardiorenal axis. She performed multiple studies on sex differences in peripheral arterial disease and is currently investigating heart failure and its interplay with kidney disease. Her thesis also has a methodological component, with a specific focus on prediction modelling.






Julia M.T. Colombijn
ORCID: 0000-0002-9022-5937
Julia is a PhD student currently finishing her medical studies. Her PhD research focuses on polypharmacy in individuals with chronic kidney disease. Besides elucidating the extent of polypharmacy in this population, she has also studied the lack of evidence for multiple common cardiorenal protective drugs and has further investigated their use in this population.






Denise M.J. Veltkamp
ORCID: 0000-0001-9914-7827
Denise is a medical doctor whose research focuses on long-term outcomes after acute kidney injury. To get a broad overview, she has performed multiple meta-analyses and clustering studies, and worked on developing prediction models to get personalised insights in these long-term outcomes. Additionally, she has previously done research on the patient perspective in kidney transplantation.






Sanne Roos
ORCID: 0009-0004-7225-8542
Sanne is a medical doctor, doing her PhD on haemodiafiltration. Not only is she investigating the possible mechanisms through which haemodiafiltraiton improves survival; she is also working to assess the effect of haemodiafiltration in a real-world population and obtain individualised estimates of its effect over haemodialysis. Prior to her PhD, she already obtained experience in dialysis research, studying the effects of incremental dialysis.






Ellis Oortwijn
ORCID: 0009-0004-5917-8716
Ellis is a PhD student with a background in cardiovascular health and disease. Bringing with her experience in both fundamental and clinical research, she now focuses on the utilisation, safety, and effectiveness of cardiovascular risk management in individuals with chronic kidney disease.





 Back to top

title: U-KREAT
text:
Hi! Welcome to the homepage of the Utrecht Kidney Research & Epidemiological Analyses Team (U-KREAT); the nephroepidemiology research group of the University Medical Center (UMC) Utrecht.
Our team is diverse in its background and specialties, but all members share the same mission: improving clinical care and outcomes for individuals with chronic kidney disease, those on dialysis, and kidney transplant recipients, using epidemiological methods and big data.
To this end, we use advanced epidemiological and data scientific methods, applied to a wide range of large and granular data sources, including randomised controlled trials, cohort studies, electronic health records, and registries.
We are located at the UMC Utrecht. Our team is embedded in the Department of Nephrology and Hypertension and in Utrecht Patient Oriented Database (UPOD) of the Central Diagnostics Laboratory.





UMC Utrecht


This collaboration gives us access both to direct clinical involvement and to the high-quality research infrastructure of UPOD.
Want to know more? Check out our currently running projects and previous output.



 Back to top

title: De nier-data onderzoeksgroep van het UMC Utrecht
text:
Welkom op de blog van U-KREAT; de nier-data onderzoeksgroep van het UMC Utrecht. Leuk dat u meeleest. Hier, op onze website, vindt u informatie over ons team en de projecten waar we mee bezig zijn. We begrijpen dat die informatie niet altijd makkelijk te lezen is, doordat het Engels is en gericht is op andere onderzoekers. Daarom hebben we ook deze blog. Op deze blog delen wij interessante informatie voor een breder publiek in begrijpbaar Nederlands, zoals dit bericht. Dit soort berichten staan onder het kopje ‘In begrijpbare taal’.



 Terug naar boven
